347.title: Exercise_261
347.md: 2.3.9*. 设 $R$ 是含幺交换环, $P_{1}, \cdots, P_{m}$ 为 $R$ 的素理想而 $A$ 为 $R$ 的理想.如果 $A \subseteq P_{1} \cup \cdots \cup P_{m}$, 则必存在某个 $i(1 \leqslant i \leqslant m)$, 使得 $A \subseteq P_{i}$.
347.formalProof:
-- Exercise 261

-- 设 R 是含幺交换环, P₁, ⋯, Pₘ 为 R 的素理想而 A 为 R 的理想. 如果 A ⊆ P₁ ∪ ⋯ ∪ Pₘ, 则必存在某个 i (1⩽i⩽m), 使得 A ⊆ Pᵢ.

-- 使用归纳法. m = 1 时显然成立. 假设命题对 m - 1 成立. 对每个 i, 考虑是否有 A ⊆ ⋃_{j ≠ i} P_j. 若成立, 则使用归纳假设, 证明结束. 若对每个 i 都不成立, 则对每个 i 存在 a_i ∈ A 使得 a_i ∈ P_i 且 a_i ∉ ⋃_{j ≠ i} P_j. 现在考虑 a = ∏_{1 ≤ j ≤ m - 1} a_j + a_m, 则由 P_m 是素理想得到 a 不在 P_m 中. 又由于 P_j (1 ≤ j ≤ m - 1) 都是理想, a 不在任意一个 P_j (1 ≤ j ≤ m - 1) 中. 于是 a ∉ A, 但这与 ∀ i, a_i ∈ A 且 A 是理想矛盾.

lemma Prime_Avoidance {R : Type} [CommRing R] (A : Ideal R) (m : ℕ)
    (P : Fin (m + 1) → Ideal R)
    (pp : ∀ i : Fin (m + 1), (P i).IsPrime)
    (hA : A.carrier ⊆ ⋃ (i : Fin (m + 1)), P i)
      : ∃ i : Fin (m + 1), A.carrier ⊆ P i := by
      -- m = 0 时, 定理显然成立.
      have case0 : m = 0 → ∃ i : Fin (m + 1), A.carrier ⊆ P i := by 
        intro hm
        use 0
        intro a ha
        let hha := Set.mem_of_mem_of_subset ha hA
        rw [Set.mem_iUnion] at hha
        rcases hha with ⟨i, hhi⟩ 
        let test := i.2
        nth_rw 2 [hm] at test
        simp at test
        rw [show 0 = ↑(0: Fin (m + 1)) from rfl] at test
        apply Fin.val_inj.mp at test
        rw [test] at hhi
        exact hhi
      -- 考虑是否存在 i 使得 A ⊆ ⋃_{j ≠ i} P_j. 
      by_cases h:(∃ i, A.carrier ⊆ ⋃ j : {j: Fin (m + 1) | j ≠ i} , P j)
      · -- 若存在, 则化为 m - 1 的情形.
        let ⟨i, hi⟩ := h
        have f := @Fintype.equivFinOfCardEq {j: Fin (m  + 1) | j ≠ i} _ m ?_
        have : ⋃ j : {j: Fin (m + 1) | j ≠ i} , ((P j): Set R) = ⋃ j : Fin m, (P (f.invFun j)) := by
          simp
          have := @Set.biUnion_range _ _ _ (f.symm) (fun j => ((P j): Set R))
          simp at this
          exact this
        rw [this] at hi
        set P' := fun j: Fin m => P (f.invFun j) with hP'
        have : ⋃ j : Fin m, (P (f.invFun j)) = ⋃ j : Fin m, ((P' j): Set R) := by
          congr
        rw [this] at hi
        · cases m with
          | -- m = 0 时, 定理显然成立.
            zero =>
            use 0
            have : ⋃ i, (P i) = (P 0 : Set R) := by
              ext x
              simp only [Set.mem_iUnion]
              exact ⟨
                fun ⟨y, hy⟩ => by
                  fin_cases y
                  exact hy,
                fun h => by use 0⟩
            exact this ▸ hA      
          | -- m > 0 时, 化为 m - 1 的情形.
            succ m' =>
            have rec_result := Prime_Avoidance A m' P' (fun _ ↦ pp _) hi
            let ⟨i, hi⟩ := rec_result
            simp [P'] at hi
            use (f.symm i)
            exact hi
        · simp
      -- 若不存在,
      push_neg at h
      -- 则对每个 i 存在 a_i ∈ A 使得 a_i ∈ P_i 且 a_i ∉ ⋃_{j ≠ i} P_j.
      have tmp : ∀ i, ∃ a ∈ A, a ∈ P i ∧ a ∉ (⋃ j ≠ i, P j) := by
        intro i
        let hh := Set.not_subset.mp (h i)
        rcases hh with ⟨a, ha⟩
        use a
        constructor
        · exact ha.1
        · constructor
          · let hha := Set.mem_of_mem_of_subset ha.1 hA
            have : ∃ k : Fin (m + 1), a ∈ P k := Set.mem_iUnion.mp hha
            rcases this with ⟨k, hk⟩
            by_cases hki : k = i
            · rw [← hki]
              exact hk 
            · have fal : a ∉ P k := by 
                simp at ha
                exact ha.2 k hki
              contradiction
          · simp only [ne_eq, Set.mem_iUnion, SetLike.mem_coe, exists_prop, not_exists, not_and]
            simp at ha
            exact ha.2
      -- 现在考虑 a = ∏_{1 ≤ j ≤ m - 1} a_j + a_m,
      let a := ∏ (i: Fin m), (tmp i).choose + (tmp m).choose
      -- 则由 P_m 是素理想得到 a 不在 P_m 中. 
      by_cases hm : m > 0
      · have a_notin_P_m : a ∉ P m := by 
          by_contra inpm 
          unfold_let at inpm
          have rt : (tmp m).choose ∈ P m := by 
            let p := Classical.choose_spec $ tmp m
            exact p.2.1
          have lt : ∏ (i: Fin m), (tmp i).choose ∈ P m := (Submodule.add_mem_iff_left (P ↑m) rt).mp inpm
          have : ∏ (i : Fin m), (tmp i).choose ∉ P m := by
            apply Finset.prod_induction_nonempty (fun (i: Fin m) => (tmp i).choose) (fun a => a ∉ P m)
            · intro a b ha hb 
              by_contra hhp
              let prime_property := @Ideal.IsPrime.mem_or_mem R _ (P m) (pp m) a b hhp
              rcases prime_property with ppp | ppp <;> contradiction
            · refine Finset.univ_nonempty_iff.mpr ?nonempty.a
              exact Fin.pos_iff_nonempty.mp hm
            · intro x hx
              have := ((tmp x).choose_spec).2.2
              by_contra hpm 
              let x' := @Nat.cast (Fin (m + 1)) _ (x.val)
              have hn : x' ≠ m := by 
                unfold_let
                apply Fin.val_inj.ne.mp
                simp
                apply Nat.ne_of_lt
                exact x.2
              have test : (tmp x).choose ∈ ⋃ j, ⋃ (_ : j ≠ x'), (P j) := by 
                rw [Set.mem_iUnion]
                use m
                exact Set.mem_iUnion_of_mem (id (Ne.symm hn)) hpm
              contradiction
          contradiction
      -- 又由于 P_j (1 ≤ j ≤ m - 1) 都是理想, a 不在任意一个 P_j (1 ≤ j ≤ m - 1) 中. 
        have a_not_in_P_j : ∀ j : Fin m, a ∉ P j := by 
          by_contra hyp
          push_neg at hyp
          rcases hyp with ⟨j, hj⟩
          unfold_let at hj
          have lt : ∏ (i: Fin m), (tmp i).choose ∈ P j := by 
            rw [<-(Finset.mul_prod_erase (a := j))]
            apply Ideal.mul_mem_right
            · let p := Classical.choose_spec $ tmp j
              exact p.2.1
            · simp
          have rt : (tmp m).choose ∈ P j := (Submodule.add_mem_iff_right (P ↑↑j) lt).mp hj
          let p := Classical.choose_spec $ tmp m
          have notm : (tmp m).choose ∉ P j := by 
            by_contra inpj
            apply p.2.2
            rw [Set.mem_iUnion]
            use j
            refine Set.mem_iUnion_of_mem ?h.i rt
            apply Fin.val_inj.ne.mp
            simp
            exact Nat.ne_of_lt j.2
          contradiction
        -- 于是 a ∉ A, 但这与 ∀ i, a_i ∈ A 且 A 是理想矛盾.
        have a_notin_A : a ∉ A := by 
          apply Set.not_mem_subset hA
          have : ⋃ (i : Fin (m + 1)), (P i).carrier = (⋃ (i : Fin m), (P i)) ∪ P m := by 
            ext x
            rw [Set.mem_iUnion]
            constructor
            · intro hyp
              rcases hyp with ⟨i, hi⟩
              by_cases hmi : i = m
              · rw [hmi] at hi 
                apply Set.mem_union_right
                exact hi
              · apply Set.mem_union_left
                rw [Set.mem_iUnion]
                use ⟨i, by 
                  refine Nat.lt_of_le_of_ne ?h₁ ?h₂
                  · exact Fin.is_le i
                  · apply Fin.val_inj.ne.mpr at hmi
                    simp at hmi
                    exact hmi
                ⟩
                simp
                exact hi 
            · intro hyp
              rw [Set.mem_union] at hyp
              rcases hyp with hhh | hhh
              · rw [Set.mem_iUnion] at hhh
                rcases hhh with ⟨i, hi⟩
                use i
                simp at hi 
                simp
                exact hi
              · use m
                exact hhh
          show a ∉ ⋃ (i : Fin (m + 1)), (P i).carrier
          rw [this]
          intro nhyp
          rw [Set.mem_union] at nhyp
          rcases nhyp with ttt | ttt
          · rw [Set.mem_iUnion] at ttt
            rcases ttt with ⟨t, ht⟩
            let test := a_not_in_P_j t
            simp at ht 
            simp at test
            contradiction
          · simp at ttt
            simp at a_notin_P_m
            contradiction
        haveI : NeZero m := NeZero.of_pos hm
        have a_in_A : a ∈ A := by 
          unfold_let
          apply Submodule.add_mem A
          · let pi := fun i => Classical.choose_spec $ tmp i
            rw [<-(Finset.mul_prod_erase (a := 0))]
            apply Ideal.mul_mem_right
            exact (pi 0).1
            simp
          · let p := Classical.choose_spec $ tmp m
            exact p.1
        contradiction
      · apply case0
        omega

354.title: Exercise_268
354.md: 2.3.2. 设 $D$ 为整环, $m$ 和 $n$ 为互素的正整数, $a, b \in D$. 如果 $a^{m}=b^{m}$, $a^{n}=b^{n}$, 求证 $a=b$.
354.formalProof:
/-
Assume that $D$ is a domain, $m$ and $n$ are coprime positive integers, $a, b \in D$. If $a^{m}=b^{m}$, $a^{n}=b^{n}$, prove that $a=b$.
-/
example {R : Type*} [Ring R] [IsDomain R] (a b : R) (m n : ℕ) (hm : m > 0) (hn : n > 0) (hmn : m.Coprime n) (h₁ : a ^ m = b ^ m) (h₂ : a ^ n = b ^ n) : a = b := by
  -- According to Bezout's lemma, $\exists x, y \in \mathbb{Z}$, such that $mx + ny = \mathrm{gcd}(m, n) = 1$.
  apply Nat.coprime_iff_gcd_eq_one.mp at hmn
  have hxy:= exists_gcd_eq_mul_add_mul (m : ℤ) (n : ℤ)
  rcases hxy with ⟨x, y, hxy⟩
  rw [← Int.coe_nat_gcd] at hmn
  have h' : gcd (m : ℤ) (n : ℤ) = (m : ℤ).gcd (n : ℤ) := rfl
  have h'' : (m : ℤ).gcd (n : ℤ) = (1 : ℤ) := congrArg Nat.cast hmn
  rw [h', h''] at hxy
  -- We discuss the positivity of $x$ and $y$, because the member of ring $R$ can't be powered by negative numbers.
  by_cases hxp : x ≥ 0
  · let x' : ℕ := x.toNat
    have hx': x' = x := Int.toNat_of_nonneg hxp
    by_cases hyp : y ≥ 0
    · -- (1) $x \ge 0$ and $y \ge 0$. Here, we know that $a = a^1 = a^{mx + ny} = (a^m)^x \cdot (a^n)^y = (b^m)^x \cdot (b^n)^y = b^{mx + ny} = b^1 = b$.
      let y' : ℕ := y.toNat
      have hy': y' = y := Int.toNat_of_nonneg hyp
      rw [← hx', ← hy'] at hxy
      have hxy' : 1 = m * x' + n * y' := Int.ofNat_inj.mp hxy
      rw [← pow_one a, ← pow_one b, hxy', pow_add, pow_add, pow_mul, pow_mul, pow_mul, pow_mul, h₁, h₂]
    · -- (2) $x \ge 0$ and $y < 0$. Here, we set $y' = -y > 0$, then we have $ny' + 1 = mx$.
      push_neg at hyp
      have : -y ≥ 0 := Int.le_of_lt (Int.neg_pos_of_neg hyp)
      let y' : ℕ := (-y).toNat
      have hy' : y' = -y := Int.toNat_of_nonneg this
      rw [← sub_neg_eq_add, neg_mul_eq_mul_neg, ← hx', ← hy'] at hxy
      apply eq_sub_iff_add_eq'.mp at hxy
      have hxy' : n * y' + 1 = m * x' := Int.ofNat_inj.mp hxy
      -- Then, we know that $a^{ny'} \cdot a = a^{ny' + 1} = a^{mx} = (a^m)^x = (b^m)^x = b^{mx} = b^{ny' + 1} = (b^n)^{y'} \cdot b = (a^n)^{y'} \cdot b = a^{ny'} \cdot b$.
      have h : a ^ (n * y') * a = a ^ (n * y') * b := by
        nth_rw 2 [← pow_one a, pow_mul]
        rw [← pow_one b, h₂, ← pow_mul, ← pow_add, ← pow_add, hxy', pow_mul, pow_mul, h₁]
      by_cases ha : a = 0
      · -- (2.i) If $a = 0$, then $b^m = 0$. Since $R$ is an integral domain, it implies that $b = 0$, so $a = b$.
        rw [ha] at h₁
        have hm' : m ≥ 1 := hm
        have hm'' : ∃ k : ℕ, m = k + 1 := Nat.exists_eq_add_of_le' hm
        rcases hm'' with ⟨k, hm''⟩
        rw [zero_pow, hm''] at h₁
        symm at h₁
        rw [ha]
        symm
        have hb : ∀ k : ℕ, b ^ (k + 1) = 0 → b = 0 := by
          intro k hk
          induction' k with d hd
          · rw [zero_add, pow_one] at hk
            exact hk
          · by_contra hb'
            push_neg at hb'
            rw [pow_add, pow_one] at hk
            apply mul_eq_zero.mp at hk
            apply or_iff_not_imp_right.mp at hk
            have hk' := hk hb'
            apply hd at hk'
            exact hb' hk'
        exact hb k h₁
        exact Nat.not_eq_zero_of_lt hm
      · -- (2.ii) If $a \ne 0$, then $a^{ny'} \ne 0$. Since $R$ is an integral domain, $a^{ny'} \cdot a = a^{ny'} \cdot b$ implies that $a = b$.
        have hne : (a ^ (n * y')) ≠ 0 := by
          have hne : ∀ k : ℕ, a ^ k ≠ 0 := by
            intro k
            induction' k with d hd
            · rw [pow_zero]
              exact one_ne_zero
            · rw [pow_add, pow_one]
              exact mul_ne_zero hd ha
          exact hne (n * y')
        exact mul_left_cancel₀ hne h
  · -- (3) $x < 0$ and $y \ge 0$. Here, we set $x' = -x > 0$, then we have $mx' + 1 = ny$. This situation is exactly the same as (2).
    push_neg at hxp
    have : -x ≥ 0 := Int.le_of_lt (Int.neg_pos_of_neg hxp)
    let x' : ℕ := (-x).toNat
    have hx' : x' = -x := Int.toNat_of_nonneg this
    by_cases hyp : y ≥ 0
    · let y' : ℕ := y.toNat
      have hy' : y' = y := Int.toNat_of_nonneg hyp
      rw [add_comm, ← sub_neg_eq_add, neg_mul_eq_mul_neg, ← hx', ← hy'
      ] at hxy
      apply eq_sub_iff_add_eq'.mp at hxy
      have hxy' : m * x' + 1 = n * y' := Int.ofNat_inj.mp hxy
      have h : a ^ (m * x') * a = a ^ (m * x') * b := by
        nth_rw 2 [← pow_one a, pow_mul]
        rw [← pow_one b, h₁, ← pow_mul, ← pow_add, ← pow_add, hxy', pow_mul, pow_mul, h₂]
      by_cases ha : a = 0
      · rw [ha] at h₂
        have hn' : n ≥ 1 := hn
        have hn'' : ∃ k : ℕ, n = k + 1 := Nat.exists_eq_add_of_le' hn
        rcases hn'' with ⟨k, hn''⟩
        rw [zero_pow, hn''] at h₂
        symm at h₂
        rw [ha]
        symm
        have hb : ∀ k : ℕ, b ^ (k + 1) = 0 → b = 0 := by
          intro k hk
          induction' k with d hd
          · rw [zero_add, pow_one] at hk
            exact hk
          · by_contra hb'
            push_neg at hb'
            rw [pow_add, pow_one] at hk
            apply mul_eq_zero.mp at hk
            apply or_iff_not_imp_right.mp at hk
            have hk' := hk hb'
            apply hd at hk'
            exact hb' hk'
        exact hb k h₂
        exact Nat.not_eq_zero_of_lt hn
      · have hne : (a ^ (m * x')) ≠ 0 := by
          have hne : ∀ k : ℕ, a ^ k ≠ 0 := by
            intro k
            induction' k with d hd
            · rw [pow_zero]
              exact one_ne_zero
            · rw [pow_add, pow_one]
              exact mul_ne_zero hd ha
          exact hne (m * x')
        exact mul_left_cancel₀ hne h
    · -- (4) $x < 0$ and $y < 0$. Since $m, n > 0$, we know that $1 = mx + ny < 0$, which leads to a contradiction.
      push_neg at hyp
      have : -y ≥ 0 := Int.le_of_lt (Int.neg_pos_of_neg hyp)
      let y' : ℕ := (-y).toNat
      have hy' : y' = -y := Int.toNat_of_nonneg this
      rw [← sub_neg_eq_add, neg_mul_eq_mul_neg, ← hy'] at hxy
      apply eq_sub_iff_add_eq'.mp at hxy
      rw [← zero_add (↑m * x), ← sub_neg_eq_add 0, neg_mul_eq_mul_neg, ← hx'] at hxy
      apply eq_sub_iff_add_eq'.mp at hxy
      rw [← add_assoc] at hxy
      apply Int.ofNat_inj.mp at hxy
      have hgt : m * x' + n * y' + 1 > 0 := by exact Nat.zero_lt_succ (m * x' + n * y')
      rw [hxy] at hgt
      tauto
354.informalProof:
Proof:

1. According to Bezout's lemma, $\exists x, y \in \mathbb{Z}$, such that $mx + ny = \mathrm{gcd}(m, n) = 1$.

2. We discuss the positivity of $x$ and $y$, because the member of ring $R$ can't be powered by negative numbers.

3. (1) $x \ge 0$ and $y \ge 0$. Here, we know that $a = a^1 = a^{mx + ny} = (a^m)^x \cdot (a^n)^y = (b^m)^x \cdot (b^n)^y = b^{mx + ny} = b^1 = b$.

4. (2) $x \ge 0$ and $y < 0$. Here, we set $y' = -y > 0$, then we have $ny' + 1 = mx$.

5. Then, we know that $a^{ny'} \cdot a = a^{ny' + 1} = a^{mx} = (a^m)^x = (b^m)^x = b^{mx} = b^{ny' + 1} = (b^n)^{y'} \cdot b = (a^n)^{y'} \cdot b = a^{ny'} \cdot b$.

6. (2.i) If $a = 0$, then $b^m = 0$. Since $R$ is an integral domain, it implies that $b = 0$, so $a = b$.

7. (2.ii) If $a \ne 0$, then $a^{ny'} \ne 0$. Since $R$ is an integral domain, $a^{ny'} \cdot a = a^{ny'} \cdot b$ implies that $a = b$.

8. (3) $x < 0$ and $y \ge 0$. Here, we set $x' = -x > 0$, then we have $mx' + 1 = ny$. This situation is exactly the same as (2).

9. (4) $x < 0$ and $y < 0$. Since $m, n > 0$, we know that $1 = mx + ny < 0$, which leads to a contradiction.

367.title: Exercise_281
367.md: 2.4.8. 如果 $D$ 为整环但不是域, 则 $D[x]$ 不是主理想整环. 特别地, $\mathbb{Z}[x]$ 不是 PID.
367.formalProof:
import Mathlib
open Polynomial

theorem not_Field_not_PID {D : Type*} [CommRing D] [IsDomain D] (not_field : ¬ IsField D) : ¬ (IsPrincipalIdealRing D[X]) := by
  -- Assume for contradiction that $D[x]$ is a principal ideal domain.
  intro PID
  -- We claim that the ideal $\langle X \rangle$ is a prime ideal.
  have PI :(Ideal.span {(X - C 0 : D[X])}).IsPrime := by
    -- It is to prove $D[X] / \langle X \rangle \cong D$ is an integral domain,
    apply (Ideal.Quotient.isDomain_iff_prime _).mp
    -- which follows from the fact that $D[X] / \langle X \rangle \cong D$ with $D$ being an integral domain.
    apply Equiv.isDomain (quotientSpanXSubCAlgEquiv 0).toRingEquiv
  -- The ideal $\langle X \rangle$ is hence a maximal ideal
  have MI : (Ideal.span {(X - C 0 : D[X])}).IsMaximal := by
    -- because $D[X]$ is a P.I.D. and every non-zero prime ideal in a P.I.D. is maximal.
    apply IsPrime.to_maximal_ideal; simp
  -- Therefore, $D$ must be a field
  have is_field : IsField D := by
    -- because $D \cong D[X] / \langle X \rangle$
    apply MulEquiv.isField _ _ (quotientSpanXSubCAlgEquiv 0).toMulEquiv.symm
    -- and $D[X] / \langle X \rangle$ is a field ($\langle X \rangle$ is a maximal ideal).
    apply (Ideal.Quotient.maximal_ideal_iff_isField_quotient _).mp MI
  -- This contradicts the assumption that $D$ is not a field.
  contradiction

example : ¬ (IsPrincipalIdealRing ℤ[X]) := by
  -- This follows directly since $\mathbb{Z}$ is an integral domain but not a field.
  apply not_Field_not_PID Int.not_isField
367.informalProof:
Theorem: If $D$ is an integral domain but not a field, then $D[x]$ is not a principal ideal domain.
Proof:
1. Assume for contradiction that $D[x]$ is a principal ideal domain.
2. We claim that the ideal $\langle X \rangle$ is a prime ideal.
3. It is to prove $D[X] / \langle X \rangle \cong D$ is an integral domain, which follows from the fact that $D[X] / \langle X \rangle \cong D$ with $D$ being an integral domain.
4. The ideal $\langle X \rangle$ is hence a maximal ideal because $D[X]$ is a P.I.D. and every non-zero prime ideal in a P.I.D. is maximal.
5. Therefore, $D$ must be a field because $D \cong D[X] / \langle X \rangle$ and $D[X] / \langle X \rangle$ is a field ($\langle X \rangle$ is a maximal ideal).
6. This contradicts the assumption that $D$ is not a field.

Corollary: $\mathbb{Z}[x]$ is not a P.I.D. since $\mathbb{Z}$ is not a field.
Proof:
1. This follows directly since $\mathbb{Z}$ is an integral domain but not a field.

380.title: Exercise_294
380.md: 1.3.14*. 设 $A \leqslant G$, 试证 $C_{G} C_{G} C_{G}(A)=C_{G}(A)$.
380.formalProof:
#check Submonoid.centralizer
example {G : Type*} [Monoid G] (A A₁ A₂ A₃: Submonoid G) {h₁: A₁= Submonoid.centralizer A}
 {h₂: A₂ = Submonoid.centralizer A₁} {h₃: A₃ = Submonoid.centralizer A₂}: A₁ = A₃ := by
--Prove $C_{G} C_{G} C_{G}(A)\supseteq C_{G}(A)$ 
--and $C_{G} C_{G} C_{G}(A)\subseteq C_{G}(A)$ respectively 
  apply le_antisymm
--Lemma 1: $A\subseteq C_{G} C_{G}(A)$
  have h: ∀ (B B₁ B₂: Submonoid G),B₁ = Submonoid.centralizer B → B₂ = Submonoid.centralizer B₁ →
  B₂ ≥ B := by 
--Fix a $y\in C_{G}(A), yx=xy$ for all $\forall x \in A$ 
--then fix a  $x\in A, \forall y \in C_{G}(A), xy=yx,
--\implies x\in C_{G} C_{G}(A) \implies A\subseteq C_{G} C_{G}(A)$  
    intro B B₁ B₂ h1 h2 x hx
    rw [h2]
    show ∀ y ∈ B₁, y * x  = x * y
    intro y hy
    rw [h1] at hy
    exact Eq.symm (SemiconjBy.eq (hy x hx))
--Replace $A$ with $C_{G}(A)$ above, we have $C_{G} C_{G} C_{G}(A)\supseteq C_{G}(A)$    
  apply h A₁ A₂ A₃ h₂ h₃
--lemma 2: $\forall X,Y\subseteq G, X\subseteq Y \implies C_{G}(X)\supseteq C_{G}(Y)$  
  have q: ∀ (X Y: Submonoid G), X ≤ Y → Submonoid.centralizer X.carrier ≥ Submonoid.centralizer Y.carrier := by
  --For any $y\in C_{G}(Y), yy'=y'y$ holds for all $y'\in Y$ 
  --thus for all $x\in X$ by $X\subseteq Y$ thus $y\in C_{G}(X) 
  --\implies C_{G}(X)\supseteq C_{G}(Y)$
    intro X Y p y hy
    show ∀ x ∈ X, x * y = y * x
    intro x hx
    have : x ∈ Y := by exact p hx 
    exact hy x (p hx)       
  rw [h₃, h₁]
--Use lemma 2. It suffices to show that $A\subseteq C_{G} C_{G}(A)$ 
--which can be concluded from lemma 1  
  apply q A A₂
  have h: ∀ (B B₁ B₂: Submonoid G),B₁ = Submonoid.centralizer B → B₂ = Submonoid.centralizer B₁ →
  B₂ ≥ B := by 
    intro B B₁ B₂ h1 h2 x hx
    rw [h2]
    show ∀ y ∈ B₁, y * x  = x * y
    intro y hy
    rw [h1] at hy
    exact Eq.symm (SemiconjBy.eq (hy x hx))
  apply h A A₁
  exact h₁
  exact h₂
380.informalProof:
设 $A \leqslant G$, 试证 $C_{G} C_{G} C_{G}(A)=C_{G}(A)$.
 Proof:
    Prove $C_{G} C_{G} C_{G}(A)\supseteq C_{G}(A)$ and $C_{G} C_{G} C_{G}(A)\subseteq C_{G}(A)$ respectively.  
    Part 1.  
    Lemma 1: $A\subseteq C_{G} C_{G}(A)$.  
    Fix a $y\in C_{G}(A), yx=xy$ for all $\forall x \in A$ then fix a  $x\in A, \forall y \in C_{G}(A), xy=yx,\implies x\in C_{G} C_{G}(A) \implies A\subseteq C_{G} C_{G}(A)$.  
    Replace $A$ with $C_{G}(A)$ above, we have $C_{G} C_{G} C_{G}(A)\supseteq C_{G}(A)$.  
    Part 2.  
    lemma 2: $\forall X,Y\subseteq G, X\subseteq Y \implies C_{G}(X)\supseteq C_{G}(Y)$.  
    For any $y\in C_{G}(Y), yy'=y'y$ holds for all $y'\in Y$ thus for all $x\in X$ by $X\subseteq Y$ thus $y\in C_{G}(X) \implies C_{G}(X)\supseteq C_{G}(Y)$.  
    Use lemma 2. It suffices to show that $A\subseteq C_{G} C_{G}(A)$ which can be concluded from lemma 1

384.title: Exercise_298
384.md: 1.6.3. 一个置换的阶等于它的轮换表示中各个轮换因子的长度的最小公倍数.
384.formalProof:
import Mathlib

namespace Equiv.Perm

open Equiv List Multiset

variable {α : Type*} [Fintype α][DecidableEq α]

example (σ : Perm α) : σ.cycleType.lcm = orderOf σ := by
  induction σ using cycle_induction_on with
  --We use induction on cycle to prove this example. 
  | base_one => simp only [cycleType_one, lcm_zero, orderOf_one]
  --Step 1 : prove $\operatorname {lcm} 1-\text{length} = |1|$ for identity perm. Trivial.
  | base_cycles σ hσ => simp only [hσ.cycleType, coe_singleton, lcm_singleton, normalize_apply,
    normUnit_eq_one, Units.val_one, mul_one, hσ.orderOf]
  --Step 2 : prove $\operatorname{lcm} (\text{length of } \sigma) = |\sigma|$ for a cycle $\sigma.$That is a standard fact.
  | induction_disjoint σ τ hd _ hσ hτ => simp only [hd.cycleType, lcm_add, hσ, hτ,
    lcm_eq_nat_lcm, hd.orderOf]
  --Step 3 : prove $\operatorname{lcm} (\text{lengths of }(\sigma \tau)) = |\sigma \tau|$ for any two cycles. That is also a standard fact.
  --The induction method is based on that each perm has cycletype i.e. Each perm could be written as finite number of some disjoint cycles.
384.informalProof:
We use induction on cycle to prove this example. $\\$
Step 1 : prove $\operatorname{lcm} (\text{length of }1) = |1|$ for identity perm.Trivial.$\\$
Step 2 : prove $\operatorname{lcm} (\text{length of } \sigma) = |\sigma|$ for a cycle $\sigma.$That is a standard fact.$\\$
Step 3 : prove $\operatorname{lcm} (\text{lengths of }(\sigma \tau)) = |\sigma \tau|$ for any two cycles. That is also a standard fact.$\\$
 --The induction method is based on that each perm has cycletype i.e. Each perm could be written as finite number of disjoint cycles.

389.title: Exercise_905
389.md: 8. Show that $G L_{n}(F)$ is non-abelian for any $n \geq 2$ and any $F$.
389.formalProof:
open Matrix Finset Classical BigOperators

/-
8. Show that $G L_{n}(F)$ is non-abelian for any $n \geq 2$ and any $F$.   
-/
example {F : Type*} [Field F]  {n : ℕ} (h : n ≥ 2) : ∃ a b : (GL (Fin n) F) , a * b ≠ b * a := by
  let const_n_minus_one : Fin n := ⟨n - 1, by refine Nat.sub_one_lt_of_le (Nat.zero_lt_of_lt h) (le_refl n)⟩
  let const_zero : Fin n := ⟨0, by linarith⟩
  --Let $c$ be a matrix with diagonal elements and the upper right block to be 1 and $d$ be a matrix with diagonal elements and lower left elements to be 1.    
  let a : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) F := of fun i j ↦ if (i = const_zero ∧ j = const_n_minus_one) then (1 : F) else (0 : F)
  let a' : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) F := of fun i j ↦ if i = const_zero ∧ j = const_n_minus_one then (-1 : F) else (0 : F)
  let b : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) F := of fun i j ↦ if (j = const_zero ∧ i = const_n_minus_one) then (1 : F) else (0 : F)
  let b' : Matrix (Fin n) (Fin n) F := of fun i j ↦ if (j = const_zero ∧ i = const_n_minus_one) then (-1 : F) else (0 : F)
  let c := a + 1
  let c':= a'+ 1
  let d := b + 1
  let d':= b'+ 1
  --We show that $c$ and $d$ belongs to $GLₙ(F)$. Let $c'$ be a matrix with diagonal elements 1 and the upper right block -1 and $d$ be a matrix with diagonal elements 1 and lower left elements -1. By calculation we can see that $c' * c = 1$ and $d' * d = 1$, so $c$ and $d$ are invertible and thus belongs to $GLₙ(F)$.   
  have hc: Invertible (Matrix.det c) := by
    apply c.detInvertibleOfLeftInverse c'
    unfold_let c c'
    simp only [mul_add, add_mul, one_mul, mul_one]
    rw [← add_assoc]
    apply add_eq_of_eq_sub
    simp only [sub_self]
    have h1: a + a' = 0 := by
      unfold_let a a'
      ext i j
      simp only [add_apply, of_apply, zero_apply]
      by_cases h: i = const_zero ∧ j = const_n_minus_one <;> simp [h]
    have h2: a' * a = 0 := by
      unfold_let a a'
      ext i j
      rw [Matrix.mul_apply]
      simp only [of_apply, mul_ite, mul_one, mul_zero, zero_apply]
      apply Finset.sum_eq_zero
      intro k _
      simp
      intro h1 _ _
      rw [h1]
      unfold_let
      simp only [Fin.mk.injEq]
      by_contra p
      have: n = 1 := by
        have h: 0 + 1 = n - 1 + 1 := by rw [p]
        have: n - 1 + 1 = n := by
          refine Nat.sub_add_cancel ?h
          linarith
        rw [this] at h; simp only [zero_add] at h
        exact h.symm
      linarith
    rw[h2, zero_add, h1]
  have hd: Invertible (Matrix.det d) := by
    apply d.detInvertibleOfLeftInverse d'
    unfold_let d d'
    simp [add_mul, mul_add]
    rw [← add_assoc]
    apply add_eq_of_eq_sub
    simp only [sub_self]
    have h1: b + b' = 0 := by
      unfold_let b b'
      ext i j
      simp only [add_apply, of_apply, zero_apply]
      by_cases h: j = const_zero ∧ i = const_n_minus_one <;> simp [h]
    have h2: b' * b = 0 := by
      unfold_let b b'
      ext i j
      rw [Matrix.mul_apply]
      simp only [of_apply, mul_ite, mul_one, mul_zero, zero_apply]
      apply Finset.sum_eq_zero
      intro k _
      simp only [ite_eq_right_iff, neg_eq_zero, one_ne_zero, imp_false, not_and, and_imp]
      intro _ h2 h3
      intro _
      rw [h3] at h2
      absurd h2
      unfold_let
      simp only [Fin.mk.injEq]
      by_contra p
      have: n = 1 := by
        have h: 0 + 1 = n - 1 + 1 := by rw [p]
        have: n - 1 + 1 = n := by
          refine Nat.sub_add_cancel ?h
          linarith
        rw [this] at h; simp only [zero_add] at h
        exact h.symm
      linarith
    rw[h2, zero_add, h1]
  let c'' : GeneralLinearGroup (Fin n) F := GeneralLinearGroup.mk' c hc
  let d'' : GeneralLinearGroup (Fin n) F := GeneralLinearGroup.mk' d hd
  have this1: n - 1 ≠ 0 := fun h => by omega
  have this2: 0 ≠ n - 1 := fun h => this1 h.symm
  --We show that $c * d ≠ d * c$, let's consider the upper left block, in $c * d$, it's 2. But in $d * c$, it's 1, thus it suffices to support that $c * d ≠ d * c$.   
  have ne : c * d ≠ d * c := by
    by_contra q
    apply Matrix.ext_iff.mpr at q
    have q1: (c * d) const_zero const_zero = 2 := by
      rw [Matrix.mul_apply]
      unfold_let c d a b
      simp
      let s1: Finset _ := {const_n_minus_one, const_zero}
      have : s1 ⊆ univ := by simp
      unfold_let const_n_minus_one
      unfold_let const_zero
      rw [(Finset.sum_subset_zero_on_sdiff this ?_ fun _ _ => rfl).symm]
      · unfold_let s1
        unfold_let const_n_minus_one
        unfold_let const_zero
        rw [Finset.sum_insert]
        simp [h, this1, this2]
        norm_num
        simp [h]
        exact fun h => by omega
      · intro x hx
        unfold_let s1 const_n_minus_one const_zero at hx
        simp at hx
        simp [hx]
    have q2: (d * c) ⟨0, by linarith⟩ ⟨0, by linarith⟩ = 1 := by
      unfold_let d c 
      simp [add_mul, mul_add]
      unfold_let b a const_zero const_n_minus_one
      rw [Matrix.mul_apply]
      simp [this1, this2]
    rw [q] at q1
    rw [q1] at q2
    have : (2: F) = 1 + 1 := by norm_num
    rw [this] at q2
    simp at q2
  --Thus $c$ $d$ is an example for the noncommutative elements in $GLₙ(F)$, this finishes the proof.    
  use c'' , d''
  have val1: (c'' * d'').1 = c * d := by rfl
  have val2: (d'' * c'').1 = d * c := by rfl
  by_contra h
  absurd ne
  rw [←val1, ←val2, h]
389.informalProof:
Proof:   
1. Let $c$ be a matrix with diagonal elements and the upper right block to be 1 and $d$ be a matrix with diagonal elements and lower left elements to be 1.    
2. We show that $c$ and $d$ belongs to $GLₙ(F)$. Let $c'$ be a matrix with diagonal elements 1 and the upper right block -1 and $d$ be a matrix with diagonal elements 1 and lower left elements -1. By calculation we can see that $c' * c = 1$ and $d' * d = 1$, so $c$ and $d$ are invertible and thus belongs to $GLₙ(F)$.   
3. We show that $c * d ≠ d * c$, let's consider the upper left block, in $c * d$, it's 2. But in $d * c$, it's 1, thus it suffices to support that $c * d ≠ d * c$.   
4. Thus $c$ $d$ is an example for the noncommutative elements in $GLₙ(F)$, this finishes the proof.

399.title: Exercise_923
399.md: 3. Let $R$ be a Euclidean Domain. Let $m$ be the minimum integer in the set of norms of nonzero elements of $R$. Prove that every nonzero element of $R$ of norm $m$ is a unit. Deduce that a nonzero element of norm zero (if such an element exists) is a unit.
399.formalProof:
/-Let $R$ be a Euclidean Domain. Let $m$ be the minimum integer in the set of norms of nonzero elements of $R$. Prove that every nonzero element of $R$ of norm $m$ is a unit. Deduce that a nonzero element of norm zero (if such an element exists) is a unit.-/
/-Suppse the norm function is $f$. We prove : If $m$ satisfy that $\forall a\in R,a\neq 0, f(a)\geq f(m)$, then m is a unit of $R$-/
example {R : Type*} [EuclideanDomain R] (m : R) (mnz : m ≠ 0) (hm : ∀ a : R, a ≠ 0 -> ¬EuclideanDomain.r a m) : IsUnit m := by
  /-Suppose $1=q*m+r$.-/
  set r := EuclideanDomain.remainder 1 m with req 
  set q := EuclideanDomain.quotient 1 m with qeq
  have quo := EuclideanDomain.quotient_mul_add_remainder_eq 1 m
  /-Then $f(r)\leq f(m)$. So $r=0$.-/
  rw [← req, ← qeq] at quo
  have rrm : EuclideanDomain.r r m := EuclideanDomain.remainder_lt 1 mnz
  have rz : r = 0 := by
    by_contra rnz 
    have := hm r rnz
    exact this rrm
  /- Thus $q*m=1$, $m$ is a unit.-/
  rw [rz, add_zero] at quo
  exact isUnit_of_mul_eq_one m q quo
399.informalProof:
Let $R$ be a Euclidean Domain. Let $m$ be the minimum integer in the set of norms of nonzero elements of $R$. Prove that every nonzero element of $R$ of norm $m$ is a unit. Deduce that a nonzero element of norm zero (if such an element exists) is a unit.

Proof:
1. Suppse the norm function is $f$. We prove : If $m$ satisfy that $\forall a\in R,a\neq 0, f(a)\geq f(m)$, then m is a unit of $R$。 
2. Suppose $1=q*m+r$. Then $f(r)\leq f(m)$. So $r=0$.
3. Thus $q*m=1$, $m$ is a unit.

402.title: Exercise_929
402.md: 23. Let $G$ be a finite group which possesses an automorphism $\sigma$ (cf. Exercise 20) such that $\sigma(g)=g$ if and only if $g=1$. If $\sigma^{2}$ is the identity map from $G$ to $G$, prove that $G$ is abelian (such an automorphism $\sigma$ is called fixed point free of order 2). [Show that every element of $G$ can be written in the form $x^{-1} \sigma(x)$ and apply $\sigma$ to such an expression.]
402.formalProof:
example {G : Type*} [Group G] [Finite G] (σ : MulEquiv G G) (h : ∀ g, σ g = g ↔ g = 1) (ids : σ ∘ σ = id) : CommGroup G := by
  -- From the assumption that $σ ∘ σ = id$, we get that $σ (σ g) = g$ for all $g$.
  have ids' (g : G) : σ (σ g) = g := congrFun ids g
  -- We have that for every $g$, there exists some $x$ such that $g = x⁻¹ * σ x$.
  have (g : G) : ∃ x, g = x⁻¹ * σ x := by
    -- Prove this by showing that function $f x = x⁻¹ * σ x$ is bijective.
    -- Since G is a finite group, we suffices to prove that f is injective.
    have : (fun x ↦ x⁻¹ * σ x).Bijective := Finite.injective_iff_bijective.mp (by
      intro x y hxy
      -- Given x and y such that x⁻¹ * σ x = y⁻¹ * σ y, prove x = y by doing some calculation.
      simp only at hxy
      have hxy : y * x⁻¹ = (σ y) * (σ x)⁻¹ := by
        rw [← mul_inv_cancel_right x⁻¹ (σ x), hxy]
        group
      have hxy : σ (y * x⁻¹) = y * x⁻¹ := by
        nth_rw 1 [hxy, map_mul, ids', map_inv, ids']
      have hxy : y * x⁻¹ = 1 := (h (y * x⁻¹)).mp hxy
      rw [← one_mul x, ← hxy, mul_assoc, mul_left_inv, mul_one]
    )
    -- Since $f$ is bijective, thus surjective, for every $g$, there exists some $x$ such that $g = f x$.
    exact (Function.Surjective.exists this.2).mp exists_eq'
  -- Using the previous result, we have that $σ g = g⁻¹$ for all $g$.
  have (g : G) : σ g = g⁻¹ := by
    rcases (this g) with ⟨x, hx⟩
    rw [hx, map_mul, map_inv, ids', mul_inv_rev, inv_inv]

  -- To show $G$ is commutative, show $a * b = b * a$ for all $a$, $b$.
  apply CommGroup.mk
  intro a b
  -- First we have $σ (a * b) = σ (b * a)$ by using $σ$'s properties.
  have : σ (a * b) = σ (b * a) := by
    calc
      _ = b⁻¹ * a⁻¹ := by rw [this, mul_inv_rev]
      _ = (σ b) * (σ a) := by rw [← this, ← this, ]
      _ = σ (b * a) := Eq.symm (map_mul σ b a)

  -- From that, we got $σ (σ (a * b)) = σ (σ (b * a))$.
  rw [← ids' (a * b), ← ids' (b * a)]
  -- Since $σ (σ g) = g$ for all $g$, we proved $a * b = b * a$.
  exact congrArg _ this
402.informalProof:
Proof. 
1. From the assumption that $σ ∘ σ = id$, we get that $σ (σ g) = g$ for all $g$.
2. We have that for every $g$, there exists some $x$ such that $g = x⁻¹ * σ x$.
3. Prove this by showing that function $f x = x⁻¹ * σ x$ is bijective.
4. Since G is a finite group, we suffices to prove that f is injective.
5. Given x and y such that x⁻¹ * σ x = y⁻¹ * σ y, prove x = y by doing some calculation.
6. Since $f$ is bijective, thus surjective, for every $g$, there exists some $x$ such that $g = f x$.
7. Using the previous result, we have that $σ g = g⁻¹$ for all $g$.
8. To show $G$ is commutative, show $a * b = b * a$ for all $a$, $b$.
9. First we have $σ (a * b) = σ (b * a)$ by using $σ$'s properties.
10. From that, we got $σ (σ (a * b)) = σ (σ (b * a))$.
11. Since $σ (σ g) = g$ for all $g$, we proved $a * b = b * a$.

403.title: Exercise_931
403.md: 23. Prove that in a Boolean ring (cf. Exercise 15 , Section 1) every prime ideal is a maximal ideal.
403.formalProof:
/-
Prove that in a Boolean ring, every prime ideal is a maximal ideal.
-/
example {R : Type*} [BooleanRing R] {I : Ideal R} (hi : I.IsPrime) : I.IsMaximal := by
  -- To prove that a prime ideal $I$ of Boolean ring $R$ is a maximal ideal, we should assume that a proper ideal $J$ of $R$ strictly includes $I$, and prove that $J = R, \ \mathrm{i.e.} \ 1 \in J$.
  apply Ideal.isPrime_iff.mp at hi
  rcases hi with ⟨hi₁, hi₂⟩
  apply Ideal.isMaximal_iff.mpr
  constructor
  · -- Firstly, $I$ should not equal to $R$. This is obvious because $I$ is a prime ideal.
    exact (Ideal.ne_top_iff_one I).mp hi₁
  · intro J x hij hx hj
    have h1 := (Ideal.ne_top_iff_one I).mp hi₁
    -- Since $I \subsetneqq J$, let $x \in J$ but $x \notin I$. Hence, we know that $x \cdot 1 \cdot (x - 1) = x \cdot x - x = 0$ since $R$ is a Boolean ring.
    have h₁ : x * 1 * (x - 1) ∈ I := by
      rw [mul_sub, mul_one, mul_one, BooleanRing.mul_self, sub_self]
      exact Submodule.zero_mem I
    -- At the same time, $x \cdot 1 \notin I$ because $I$ is a prime ideal and $x, 1 \notin I$.
    have h₂ : x * 1 ∉ I := by
      by_contra h₂
      apply hi₂ at h₂
      tauto
    -- Hence, we know $x - 1 \in I \le J$. Using $x \in J$ we get $1 \in J$, indicating $J = R$, so $I$ is a maximal ideal.
    have h₃ := sub_mem hj (hij (or_iff_not_imp_left.mp (hi₂ h₁) h₂))
    rw [← sub_add, sub_self, zero_add] at h₃
    exact h₃
403.informalProof:
Proof:

1. To prove that a prime ideal $I$ of Boolean ring $R$ is a maximal ideal, we should assume that a proper ideal $J$ of $R$ strictly includes $I$, and prove that $J = R, \ \mathrm{i.e.} \ 1 \in J$.

2. Firstly, $I$ should not equal to $R$. This is obvious because $I$ is a prime ideal.

3. Since $I \subsetneqq J$, let $x \in J$ but $x \notin I$. Hence, we know that $x \cdot 1 \cdot (x - 1) = x \cdot x - x = 0$ since $R$ is a Boolean ring.

4. At the same time, $x \cdot 1 \notin I$ because $I$ is a prime ideal and $x, 1 \notin I$.

5. Hence, we know $x - 1 \in I \le J$. Using $x \in J$ we get $1 \in J$, indicating $J = R$, so $I$ is a maximal ideal.

424.title: Exercise_962
424.md: 1. Prove that $C_{G}(A)=\left\{g \in G \mid g^{-1} a g=a\right.$ for all $\left.a \in A\right\}$.
424.formalProof:
/-
Prove that $C_{G}(A)=\left\{g \in G \mid g^{-1} a g=a\right.$ for all $\left.a \in A\right\}$.
-/
example {G : Type*} {A : Set G} [Group G] : Subgroup.centralizer A = {g : G | ∀ a ∈ A, g⁻¹ * a * g = a} := by
  -- We prove that $C_G(A) \subseteq \{ g \in G \ | \ \forall a \in A, \ g^{-1}ag = a \}$ and $\{ g \in G \ | \ \forall a \in A, \ g^{-1}ag = a \} \subseteq C_G(A)$.
  apply Set.Subset.antisymm
  · intro g hg
    -- First, for $g \in C_G(A)$, it satisfies that $\forall a \in A, \ ag = ga$. Then, $\forall a \in A, \ g^{-1}ag = g^{-1}ga = a, \ \mathrm{i.e.} \ g \in \{ g \in G \ | \ \forall a \in A, \ g^{-1}ag = a \}$.
    apply Subgroup.mem_centralizer_iff.mp at hg
    apply Set.mem_setOf.mpr
    intro a ha
    have ha' := hg a ha
    rw [mul_assoc, ha', ← mul_assoc, mul_left_inv, one_mul]
  · intro g hg
    -- Second, for $g \in \{ g \in G \ | \ \forall a \in A, \ g^{-1}ag = a \} , \ \forall a \in A, \ ga = g(g^{-1}ag) = ag, \ \mathrm{i.e.} \ g \in C_G(A)$.
    apply Subgroup.mem_centralizer_iff.mpr
    apply Set.mem_setOf.mp at hg
    intro a ha
    have ha' := hg a ha
    nth_rw 2 [← ha']
    group
424.informalProof:
Proof:

1. We prove that $C_G(A) \subseteq \{ g \in G \ | \ \forall a \in A, \ g^{-1}ag = a \}$ and $\{ g \in G \ | \ \forall a \in A, \ g^{-1}ag = a \} \subseteq C_G(A)$.

2. First, for $g \in C_G(A)$, it satisfies that $\forall a \in A, \ ag = ga$. Then, $\forall a \in A, \ g^{-1}ag = g^{-1}ga = a, \ \mathrm{i.e.} \ g \in \{ g \in G \ | \ \forall a \in A, \ g^{-1}ag = a \}$.

3. Second, for $g \in \{ g \in G \ | \ \forall a \in A, \ g^{-1}ag = a \} , \ \forall a \in A, \ ga = g(g^{-1}ag) = ag, \ \mathrm{i.e.} \ g \in C_G(A)$.

436.title: Exercise_979
436.md: 3. Determine the fixed field of complex conjugation on $\mathbb{C}$.
436.formalProof:
import Mathlib.Tactic
import MIL.common
import Mathlib.Data.Complex.Basic

open ComplexConjugate
-- Prove that the set of complex numbers fixed by conjugation is the set of real numbers
example : {z : ℂ | conj z = z} = {z : ℂ | ∃ (x : ℝ), z = x} := by
  ext y
  dsimp
  constructor
  -- Prove the forward direction: if conj y = y, then y is a real number
  · intro h
    use y.re
    rw [Complex.conj_eq_iff_re] at h
    exact h.symm
  -- Prove the reverse direction: if y is a real number, then conj y = y
  · intro h
    rw [Complex.conj_eq_iff_re]
    rw [Complex.ext_iff]
    dsimp
    rcases h with ⟨x, hx⟩
    rw [Complex.ext_iff] at hx
    dsimp at hx
    constructor
    rfl
    rw [hx.2]
436.informalProof:
Prove that the set of complex numbers fixed by conjugation is the set of real numbers
Prove the forward direction: if conj y = y, then y is a real number
Prove the reverse direction: if y is a real number, then conj y = y

437.title: Exercise_981
437.md: 10. Assume $R$ is commutative. Prove that if $P$ is a prime ideal of $R$ and $P$ contains no zero divisors then $R$ is an integral domain.
437.formalProof:
/-
Assume $R$ is commutative. Prove that if $P$ is a prime ideal of $R$ and $P$ contains no zero divisors then $R$ is an integral domain.
-/
example {R : Type*} [CommRing R] {P : Ideal R} [Nontrivial P] (_ : P.IsPrime) (hz : ∀ a : P, ∀ b : R, a * b = 0 → a = 0 ∨ b = 0) : IsDomain R where
  -- Since $R$ is already commutative, we just have to prove that $R$ isn't trivial, and $R$ satisfies the left and right cancellation of multiplication.
  mul_left_cancel_of_ne_zero := by
    intro a b c ha hbc
    -- For $a, b, c \in R$ in which $a \ne 0$, we just have to prove that $ab = ac$ implies $b = c$. Let $0 \ne p \in P$, then $pa, bp, cp \in P$ since $P$ is an ideal.
    have hp := exists_ne (0 : P)
    rcases hp with ⟨p, hp⟩
    have hxp : ∀ x : R, x * p ∈ P := fun x ↦ Ideal.mul_mem_left P x (Submodule.coe_mem p)
    -- From $ab = ac$ we know that $pabp = pacp$, so $pa (bp - cp) = 0$. Hence, $pa = 0$ or $bp - cp = 0$.
    have h₁ : (p * a) * (b * p) = (p * a) * (c * p) := by rw [← mul_assoc, ← mul_assoc, mul_assoc (p : R), hbc, ← mul_assoc]
    have hpa := hxp a
    rw [mul_comm] at hpa
    have h₂ : (p * a) * (b * p - c * p) = 0 := by rw [mul_sub, h₁, sub_self]
    have h₃ := hz ⟨(p * a), hpa⟩ (b * p - c * p) h₂
    -- Since $a, p \ne 0 $ and $P$ contains no zero divisors, we know $pa \ne 0$, so $bp - cp = 0, \ \mathrm{i.e.} \ bp = cp$.
    have ha' : (⟨(p * a), hpa⟩ : P) ≠ 0 := by
      by_contra ha'
      simp only [AddSubmonoid.mk_eq_zero] at ha'
      apply hz at ha'
      exact ha (or_iff_not_imp_left.mp ha' hp)
    have h₄ := or_iff_not_imp_left.mp h₃ ha'
    simp only [AddSubmonoid.mk_eq_zero] at h₄
    -- Since $P$ contains no zero divisors, $P$ satisfies right cancellation of multiplication, so $bp = cp$ implies $b = c$.
    rw [← sub_mul, mul_comm] at h₄
    apply hz at h₄
    apply eq_of_sub_eq_zero (or_iff_not_imp_left.mp h₄ hp)
  mul_right_cancel_of_ne_zero := by
    -- For the right cancellation part, since $P$ is commutative, it is obviously proven by above.
    intro b a c ha hbc
    rw [mul_comm b, mul_comm c] at hbc
    have hp := exists_ne (0 : P)
    rcases hp with ⟨p, hp⟩
    have hxp : ∀ x : R, x * p ∈ P := fun x ↦ Ideal.mul_mem_left P x (Submodule.coe_mem p)
    have h₁ : (p * a) * (b * p) = (p * a) * (c * p) := by rw [← mul_assoc, ← mul_assoc, mul_assoc (p : R), hbc, ← mul_assoc]
    have hpa := hxp a
    rw [mul_comm] at hpa
    have h₂ : (p * a) * (b * p - c * p) = 0 := by rw [mul_sub, h₁, sub_self]
    have h₃ := hz ⟨(p * a), hpa⟩ (b * p - c * p) h₂
    have ha' : (⟨(p * a), hpa⟩ : P) ≠ 0 := by
      by_contra ha'
      simp only [AddSubmonoid.mk_eq_zero] at ha'
      apply hz at ha'
      exact ha (or_iff_not_imp_left.mp ha' hp)
    have h₄ := or_iff_not_imp_left.mp h₃ ha'
    simp only [AddSubmonoid.mk_eq_zero] at h₄
    rw [← sub_mul, mul_comm] at h₄
    apply hz at h₄
    apply eq_of_sub_eq_zero (or_iff_not_imp_left.mp h₄ hp)
  exists_pair_ne := by
    -- Since $P$ isn't trivial, $R$ is also nontrivial.
    have h := exists_pair_ne P
    rcases h with ⟨x, y, h⟩
    use (x : R), (y : R)
    exact Subtype.coe_ne_coe.mpr h
437.informalProof:
Proof:

1. Since $R$ is already commutative, we just have to prove that $R$ isn't trivial, and $R$ satisfies the left and right cancellation of multiplication.

2. For $a, b, c \in R$ in which $a \ne 0$, we just have to prove that $ab = ac$ implies $b = c$. Let $0 \ne p \in P$, then $pa, bp, cp \in P$ since $P$ is an ideal.

3. From $ab = ac$ we know that $pabp = pacp$, so $pa (bp - cp) = 0$. Hence, $pa = 0$ or $bp - cp = 0$.

4. Since $a, p \ne 0 $ and $P$ contains no zero divisors, we know $pa \ne 0$, so $bp - cp = 0, \ \mathrm{i.e.} \ bp = cp$.

5. Since $P$ contains no zero divisors, $P$ satisfies right cancellation of multiplication, so $bp = cp$ implies $b = c$.

6. For the right cancellation part, since $P$ is commutative, it is obviously proven by above.

7. Since $P$ isn't trivial, $R$ is also nontrivial.

496.title: Exercise_1196
496.md: 6. Let $H \leq G$ and let $g \in G$. Prove that if the right coset $H g$ equals some left coset of $H$ in $G$ then it equals the left coset $g H$ and $g$ must be in $N_{G}(H)$.
496.formalProof:
import Mathlib
open Set
open Subgroup
open scoped Pointwise

-- Definitions and necessary imports
variable {G : Type*} [Group G] {H : Subgroup G} {g : G}

-- Theorem: If the right coset Hg equals some left coset of H in G, then it equals the left coset gH and g must be in NG(H)
theorem right_coset_eq_left_coset (h : ∃ g' : G, MulOpposite.op g • H.carrier = g' • H.carrier) :
  MulOpposite.op g • H.carrier = g • H.carrier ∧ g ∈ Subgroup.normalizer H := by
  -- Assume Hg equals some left coset of H in G, say g'H.
  rcases h with ⟨g', hcoset⟩
  
  -- Show that g is in the right coset Hg.
  have : g ∈ MulOpposite.op g • H.carrier := by
    apply (mem_rightCoset_iff g).mpr
    simp
    exact Subgroup.one_mem H
  
  -- Rewrite the assumption with the given coset equality.
  rw [hcoset] at this
  rw [hcoset]
  rcases this with ⟨h1, h⟩
  simp at *
  
  -- Prove that g' • H.carrier = g • H.carrier.
  have hp: g' • H.carrier = g • H.carrier := by
    ext x
    constructor
    -- First direction: g' • H.carrier ⊆ g • H.carrier
    · intro hh
      rcases hh with ⟨h2, hh⟩
      simp at hh
      use h1⁻¹ * h2
      simp
      constructor
      · have: h1⁻¹ ∈ H := by apply (Subgroup.inv_mem_iff H).mpr; exact h.1
        have this2: h2 ∈ H := by exact hh.1
        exact (Subgroup.mul_mem_cancel_right H this2).mpr this
      · rw [← h.2, ← hh.2]
        group
    -- Second direction: g • H.carrier ⊆ g' • H.carrier
    · intro hh
      rcases hh with ⟨h2, hh⟩
      simp at hh
      use h1 * h2
      simp
      constructor
      · have: h1 ∈ H := by exact h.1
        have this2: h2 ∈ H := by exact hh.1
        exact (Subgroup.mul_mem_cancel_right H this2).mpr this
      · rw [← hh.2, ← h.2, mul_assoc]
  
  constructor
  -- Show that Hg = gH
  · exact hp
  
  -- Prove that g is in the normalizer of H
  · rw [hp] at hcoset
    have: H = g⁻¹ • (MulOpposite.op g • H.carrier) := by
      exact eq_inv_smul_iff.mpr (id (Eq.symm hcoset))
    apply mem_normalizer_iff''.mpr
    intro hh
    constructor
    -- First part: gHg⁻¹ ⊆ H
    · intro hpp
      have t1: ∃ ht: H, g⁻¹ * hh * g = ht := by
        simp only [Subtype.exists, exists_prop, exists_eq_right']
        have t2: g⁻¹ * hh * g ∈ g⁻¹ • MulOpposite.op g • H.carrier := by
          apply mem_inv_smul_set_iff.mpr
          apply (mem_rightCoset_iff g).mpr
          simp
          group
          exact hpp
        rw [← this] at t2
        exact t2
      rcases t1 with ⟨ht, t1⟩
      rw [t1]
      exact SetLike.coe_mem ht
    -- Second part: H ⊆ gHg⁻¹
    · intro hpp
      have t1: ∃ ht: H, g⁻¹ * hh * g = ht := by
        simp
        exact hpp
      rcases t1 with ⟨ht, t1⟩
      have t2: ∃ htt: H, g⁻¹ * htt * g = ht := by
        have t3: ht.1 ∈ g⁻¹ • MulOpposite.op g • H.carrier := by
          rw [← this]
          exact ht.2
        rcases t3 with ⟨l, hl⟩
        simp at hl
        rcases hl.1 with ⟨l1, hl1⟩
        simp at hl1
        use ⟨l1, hl1.1⟩
        simp
        rw [mul_assoc, hl1.2, hl.2]
      rcases t2 with ⟨htt, t2⟩
      rw [← t1] at t2
      simp at t2
      rw [← t2]
      exact SetLike.coe_mem htt
496.informalProof:
# Informal Proof

**Theorem**: If the right coset \( Hg \) equals some left coset of \( H \) in \( G \), then it equals the left coset \( gH \) and \( g \) must be in the normalizer of \( H \) in \( G \).

**Proof**:

1. **Assumption**: Suppose \( Hg = g'H \) for some \( g' \in G \). We need to show that \( Hg = gH \) and \( g \in N_G(H) \) (the normalizer of \( H \) in \( G \)).

2. **Step 1: Prove \( Hg = gH \)**
    - By assumption, we have \( Hg = g'H \).
    - We need to show that \( g'H \subseteq gH \) and \( gH \subseteq g'H \).

    - For \( g'H \subseteq gH \):
        - Take any element \( x \in g'H \). Then \( x = g'h \) for some \( h \in H \).
        - Since \( g' = gk \) for some \( k \in H \), we have \( x = gkh \).
        - We can write \( h = h_1h_2 \) for some \( h_1, h_2 \in H \), so \( x = g(kh_1)h_2 \in gH \).
    
    - For \( gH \subseteq g'H \):
        - Take any element \( x \in gH \). Then \( x = gh \) for some \( h \in H \).
        - Since \( g = g'k \) for some \( k \in H \), we have \( x = g'kh \).
        - We can write \( h = h_1h_2 \) for some \( h_1, h_2 \in H \), so \( x = g'(kh_1)h_2 \in g'H \).

3. **Step 2: Prove \( g \in N_G(H) \)**
    - The normalizer \( N_G(H) \) of \( H \) in \( G \) is defined as:
      \[ N_G(H) = \{ g \in G \mid gHg^{-1} \subseteq H \} \]
    
    - To show \( g \in N_G(H) \), we need to prove that for all \( h \in H \), \( ghg^{-1} \in H \).
    
    - By the previous steps, we have \( Hg = gH \). This implies:
      \[ gHg^{-1} = H \]
    
    - Therefore, for any \( h \in H \), we have \( ghg^{-1} \in H \). Hence, \( g \in N_G(H) \).

### Conclusion

We have shown that if the right coset \( Hg \) equals some left coset of \( H \) in \( G \), then it must equal the left coset \( gH \) and \( g \) must be in the normalizer of \( H \) in \( G \). This completes the proof.

544.title: Example_8003B
544.md:
Let $G$ be a group, and $a, b \in G$. For any positive integer $n$ we define $a^{n}$ by $a^{n}=\underbrace{a a a \cdots a}_{n \text { factors }}$

If there is an element $x \in G$ such that $a=x^{2}$, we say that $a$ has a square root in $G$. Similarly, if $a=y^{3}$ for some $y \in G$, we say $a$ has a cube root in $G$. In general, $a$ has an $n$th root in $G$ if $a=z^{n}$ for some $z \in G$. Prove
$1\left(b a b^{-1}\right)^{n}=b a^{n} b^{-1}$, for every positive integer Prove by induction.
544.formalProof:
example {G : Type} [Group G] (a b:G) (n:ℕ) : (b*a*b⁻¹)^n=b*a^n*b⁻¹ := by
  --用归纳法
  induction' n with n ih
  · simp only [pow_zero, mul_one, mul_right_inv]
  · calc
    _ = (b * a * b⁻¹) ^ n * (b * a * b⁻¹) :=by simp only [pow_succ]
    --使用归纳假设后就简单了
    _ = b*a^n*b⁻¹ * (b * a * b⁻¹) :=by simp only [ih]
    _ = b*(a^n*a)*b⁻¹ :=by group
    _ = _ :=by simp only [pow_succ]
544.informalProof:
1、用归纳法，使用归纳假设简化即可

2、同时归纳(a*b)^n=a^n*b^n 以及 b^n*a=a*b^n

2.1、归纳前式要用到b^n*a=a*b^n，所以才需要同时归纳之

2.2、后式的根本原因是a，b可交换

3、用归纳法，2^(2*(n+1))化成^(2*n+1+1)的形式，容易使用pow_succ定理

555.title: Exercise_1579
555.md: 2 Show that $\mathbf{z}_{10}$ is generated by 2 and 5 .
555.formalProof:
import Mathlib

theorem task941 : Subgroup.closure ({x | x = (2 : ZMod 10) ∨ x = (5 : ZMod 10)} : Set (Multiplicative (ZMod 10))) = (⊤ : Subgroup (Multiplicative (ZMod 10))) := by
  let clos : Subgroup (Multiplicative (ZMod 10)) := Subgroup.closure ({x | x = (2 : ZMod 10) ∨ x = (5 : ZMod 10)} : Set (Multiplicative (ZMod 10)))
  have l₂ : (2 : ZMod 10) ∈ ({x | x = (2 : ZMod 10) ∨ x = (5 : ZMod 10)} : Set (Multiplicative (ZMod 10))) := by
    left
    rfl
  have e₂ : (2 : ZMod 10) ∈ clos := Subgroup.subset_closure l₂
  have l₅ : (5 : ZMod 10) ∈ ({x | x = (2 : ZMod 10) ∨ x = (5 : ZMod 10)} : Set (Multiplicative (ZMod 10))) := by
    right
    rfl
  have e₅ : (5 : ZMod 10) ∈ clos := Subgroup.subset_closure l₅
  have pow (k : ZMod 10) (e : k ∈ clos) : ∀ n : ℕ, n • (k : ZMod 10) ∈ clos := by
    intro n
    induction n
    case zero =>
      rw [zero_smul]
      exact Subgroup.one_mem clos
    case succ n ih =>
      rw [add_smul,one_smul]
      exact Subgroup.mul_mem clos ih e
  -- $1 = 3 * 2 + 5 \in \left\langle 2,5 \right\rangle$
  have e₁ : (1 : ZMod 10) ∈ clos := by
    have : (1 : ZMod 10) = 3 • (2 : ZMod 10) + (5 : ZMod 10) := by decide
    exact Subgroup.mul_mem clos (pow 2 e₂ 3) e₅
  have : ∀ n : ZMod 10, n = n.val • (1 : ZMod 10) := by decide
  have : ∀ n : ZMod 10, n ∈ clos := by
    intro n
    rw [this n]
    exact pow 1 e₁ n.val
  exact (Subgroup.eq_top_iff' clos).mpr this

556.title: Exercise_1582
556.md: 5 Show that every integer $z$ is generated by 5 and 7 .
556.formalProof:
import Mathlib

-- Theorem: For every integer z, there exist integers a and b such that z = 5a + 7b.
example : ∀ z : ℤ, ∃ a b : ℤ, z = a * 5 + b * 7 := by
  -- Introduce an arbitrary integer z.
  intro z
  -- Choose a = 3 * z and b = -2 * z.
  use 3 * z, -2 * z
  -- Simplify the expression to show that z = 5 * (3 * z) + 7 * (-2 * z).
  group
556.informalProof:
# Informal Proof

**Theorem**: For every integer \( z \), there exist integers \( a \) and \( b \) such that \( z = 5a + 7b \).

**Proof**:

Let \( z \) be an arbitrary integer. We aim to show that \( z \) can be written as a linear combination of 5 and 7. Specifically, we need to find integers \( a \) and \( b \) such that \( z = 5a + 7b \).

Consider the following choices:
- Let \( a = 3z \)
- Let \( b = -2z \)

Now, let's verify that these choices satisfy the equation \( z = 5a + 7b \):

\[
\begin{align*}
5a + 7b &= 5(3z) + 7(-2z) \\
&= 15z - 14z \\
&= z
\end{align*}
\]

Thus, we have found that for any integer \( z \), there exist integers \( a = 3z \) and \( b = -2z \) such that \( z = 5a + 7b \). Therefore, \( \mathbb{Z} \) is generated by 5 and 7.

This completes the proof.

628.title: Exercise_1680
628.md: Suppose $g=(a, b) \in G \times H$, where $a$ has order $m$ and $b$ has order $n$. Prove that $\operatorname{ord}(g)=\operatorname{LCM}(m,n)$.
628.formalProof:
import Mathlib.Algebra.Group.Subgroup.ZPowers
import Mathlib.Tactic
import Mathlib.Algebra.Group.MinimalAxioms


section Example_1415B
/-
-/
/-
Let $G$ and $H$ be groups. Suppose $g=(a, b) \in G \times H$, where $a$ has order $m$ and $b$ has order $n$. Prove that $\operatorname{ord}(g)=\operatorname{LCM}(m,n)$.
-/
example {G H : Type*} [Group G] [Group H] {a : G} {b : H} : orderOf (a, b) = Nat.lcm (orderOf a) (orderOf b) := by
  --Note that $x = (a,b)$
  let x : G × H := (a, b)
  --We have $m \mid orderOf x$ because $x^{orderOf x} = (1,*)$,i.e $a ^ {orderOf x} = 1$
  have dvd1 : orderOf a ∣ orderOf x := by
    apply orderOf_dvd_of_pow_eq_one
    calc
      _ = (x ^ orderOf x).1 := rfl
      _ = _ := by simp only [pow_orderOf_eq_one x, Prod.fst_one]
  --We have $n \mid orderOf x$ as the same reason
  have dvd2 : orderOf b ∣ orderOf x := by
    apply orderOf_dvd_of_pow_eq_one
    calc
      _ = (x ^ orderOf x).2 := rfl
      _ = _ := by simp only [pow_orderOf_eq_one x, Prod.snd_one]
  --Hence we prove that $\operatorname{LCM}(m,n) \mid orderOf x$
  have h1 : Nat.lcm (orderOf a) (orderOf b) ∣ orderOf x :=  Nat.lcm_dvd dvd1 dvd2
  --We will $orderOf x \mid \operatorname{LCM}(m,n)$
  have h2 : orderOf x ∣ Nat.lcm (orderOf a) (orderOf b) := by
    apply orderOf_dvd_of_pow_eq_one
    -- by prove $a ^ {\operatorname{LCM}(m,n)} = 1$
    have eq1 : a ^ Nat.lcm (orderOf a) (orderOf b) = 1:= by
      apply orderOf_dvd_iff_pow_eq_one.mp
      exact Nat.dvd_lcm_left (orderOf a) (orderOf b)
    -- and $b ^ {\operatorname{LCM}(m,n)} = 1$
    have eq2 : b ^ Nat.lcm (orderOf a) (orderOf b) = 1:= by
      apply orderOf_dvd_iff_pow_eq_one.mp
      exact Nat.dvd_lcm_right (orderOf a) (orderOf b)
    calc
    _ = (a ^ Nat.lcm (orderOf a) (orderOf b), b ^ Nat.lcm (orderOf a) (orderOf b)) := rfl
    _ = _ := by simp only [eq1, eq2, Prod.mk_eq_one, and_self]
  --We have prove that $orderOf x = \operatorname{LCM}(m,n)$
  apply Nat.dvd_antisymm h2 h1

end Example_1415B
628.informalProof:
Let $G$ and $H$ be groups. Suppose $g=(a, b) \in G \times H$, where $a$ has order $m$ and $b$ has order $n$. Prove that $\operatorname{ord}(g)=\operatorname{LCM}(m,n)$.

0.Note that $x = (a,b)$

1.We have $m \mid orderOf x$ because $x^{orderOf x} = (1,*)$,i.e $a ^ {orderOf x} = 1$

2.We have $n \mid orderOf x$ as the same reason

3.Hence we prove that $\operatorname{LCM}(m,n) \mid orderOf x$

4.We will $orderOf x \mid \operatorname{LCM}(m,n)$ by prove $a ^ {\operatorname{LCM}(m,n)} = 1$ and $b ^ {\operatorname{LCM}(m,n)} = 1$

5.We have prove that $orderOf x = \operatorname{LCM}(m,n)$

630.title: Example_1682
630.md: 6 Suppose $(c, d) \in G \times H$, where $c$ has order $m$ and $d$ has order $n$. Prove: If $m$ and $n$ are not relatively prime (hence have a common factor $q>1$ ), then the order of $(c, d)$ is less than $m n$.
630.formalProof:
example (G H : Type*) [Group G] [Group H] (c : G) (d : H) (m n : ℕ) (k1 : m > 0) (k2 : n > 0) (k3: orderOf c = m) (k4 : orderOf d = n ) (k5 : m.gcd n > 1): orderOf (c, d) < m * n := by
  have lemma1 : orderOf (c, d) = Nat.lcm (orderOf c) (orderOf d):= by
  --We first prove a lemma : orderOf (c, d) = Nat.lcm (orderOf c) (orderOf d).
    refine Nat.dvd_antisymm ?_ ?_
    --Divide the problem into two parts, so we only need to prove that both sides can be divided by the other.
    · have h1 : (c, d) ^ (orderOf c).lcm (orderOf d) = 1 := by
     --For the first part, we first want to prove h1 : (c, d) ^ (orderOf c).lcm (orderOf d) = 1.
        refine Eq.symm (Prod.ext ?_ ?_)
       --Then, we separate the equasion into two parts by definition.
        · symm
          dsimp
          have h2 : (orderOf c) ∣ (orderOf c).lcm (orderOf d) := by
            exact Nat.dvd_lcm_left (orderOf c) (orderOf d)
          exact orderOf_dvd_iff_pow_eq_one.mp h2
        --For the first part, since we can prove h2 : (orderOf c) ∣ (orderOf c).lcm (orderOf d) by definition, we can easily reach the goal.
        · symm
          dsimp
          have h2 : (orderOf d) ∣ (orderOf c).lcm (orderOf d) := by
            exact Nat.dvd_lcm_right (orderOf c) (orderOf d)
          exact orderOf_dvd_iff_pow_eq_one.mp h2
        --For the second part, we can finish the proof in the same way.
      exact orderOf_dvd_of_pow_eq_one h1
      --Finally, by using the facts about order, we can directly reach the conclusion of the first half.

    · have h1 : (c, d) ^ orderOf (c, d) = 1 := by
       exact pow_orderOf_eq_one (c, d)
      simp only [Prod.pow_mk, Prod.mk_eq_one] at h1
      --For the second half, by using the definition of order, we can get that c ^ orderOf (c, d) = 1 and d ^ orderOf (c, d) = 1.
      refine Nat.lcm_dvd ?refine_2.H1 ?refine_2.H2
      --By using the definition of lcm, we can also separate the problem into two parts.
      · have h2 : c ^ orderOf (c, d) = 1 := by exact h1.1
        exact orderOf_dvd_of_pow_eq_one h2
      · have h2 : d ^ orderOf (c, d) = 1 := by exact h1.2
        exact orderOf_dvd_of_pow_eq_one h2
      --At last, by just using the definition and easy facts about order, we can prove the two parts without any difficulty. This finishes the proof of the lemma.
  have lemma2 : orderOf (c, d) = m.lcm n := by
    rw [← k3, ← k4]
    exact lemma1
  --Then, by using the given information and the lemma, we can get that orderOf (c, d) = m.lcm n.
  have lemma3 : m * n = (Nat.gcd m n) * (Nat.lcm m n) := by
    exact Eq.symm (Nat.gcd_mul_lcm m n)
  --Besides we can use the theorem : m * n = (Nat.gcd m n) * (Nat.lcm m n).
  rw [lemma3, lemma2]
  refine (Nat.lt_mul_iff_one_lt_left ?hb).mpr k5
  exact Nat.lcm_pos k1 k2
  --After that, by rewriting the goal with all the facts we have got, the conclusion becomes obvious. This finishes the whole proof.
630.informalProof:
Proof:
1. We first prove a lemma : orderOf (c, d) = Nat.lcm (orderOf c) (orderOf d).
2. Divide the problem into two parts, so we only need to prove that both sides can be divided by the other.
3. For the first part, we first want to prove h1 : (c, d) ^ (orderOf c).lcm (orderOf d) = 1.
4. Then, we separate the equasion into two parts by definition.
5. For the first part, since we can prove h2 : (orderOf c) ∣ (orderOf c).lcm (orderOf d) by definition, we can easily reach the goal.
6. For the second part, we can finish the proof in the same way.
7. Finally, by using the facts about order, we can directly reach the conclusion of the first half.
8. For the second half, by using the definition of order, we can get that c ^ orderOf (c, d) = 1 and d ^ orderOf (c, d) = 1.
9. By using the definition of lcm, we can also separate the problem into two parts.
10. At last, by just using the definition and easy facts about order, we can prove the two parts without any difficulty. This finishes the proof of the lemma.
11. Then, by using the given information and the lemma, we can get that orderOf (c, d) = m.lcm n.
12. Besides we can use the theorem : m * n = (Nat.gcd m n) * (Nat.lcm m n).
13. After that, by rewriting the goal with all the facts we have got, the conclusion becomes obvious. This finishes the whole proof.

691.title: Exercise_1757
691.md:
1. In a ring with unity, prove that if $a$ is nilpotent, then $a+1$ and $a-1$ are both invertible. [HinT: Use the factorization

$$

1-a^{n}=(1-a)\left(1+a+a^{2}+\cdots+a^{n-1}\right)

$$

for $1-a$, and a similar formula for $1+a$.]

2. In a commutative ring, prove that any product $x a$ of a nilpotent element $a$ by any element $x$ is nilpotent.

3.
In a commutative ring, prove that the sum of two nilpotent elements is nilpotent. (HinT: You must use the binomial formula; see Exercise L.)

An element $a$ of a ring is **unipotent** iff $1-a$ is nilpotent.

4. In a commutative ring, prove that the product of two unipotent elements $a$ and $b$ is unipotent. [HinT: Use the binomial formula to expand $1-a b=(1-a)+a(1-b)$ to power $n+m$.]

5. In a ring with unity, prove that every unipotent element is invertible. (Hint: Use Part 1.)
691.formalProof:
theorem inv {R : Type*} [Ring  R] (a : R) {h : IsNilpotent a}: (∃ (r : R), (1 + a) * r = 1) ∧ (∃ (s : R), (1 - a) * s = 1) := by
  constructor
--1. $\because a$ is nilpotent $\therefore \exist n\in\mathbb N,s.t. a^{n}=0$.   
  rcases h with ⟨n,hn⟩
--Thus $1=1 - a^{n}=(1-a)(1+a+a^{2}+\cdots+a^{n-1})$ Thus $1-a$ is invertible  
  have h₁: (1 + a) * (∑ i ∈ Finset.range n, (-a) ^ i) = 1 - (-a) ^ n := by
    have h: 1 + a = 1 - (-a) := by 
      exact Eq.symm (sub_neg_eq_add 1 a)
    rw [h]
    exact mul_neg_geom_sum (-a) n  
  use (∑ i ∈ Finset.range n, (-a) ^ i)
  have h₂: (-a) ^ n = (-1) ^ n * a ^ n := by exact neg_pow a n  
  have p: (-a) ^ n = 0 := by 
    rw [h₂, hn]
    ring_nf
    exact neg_one_pow_mul_eq_zero_iff.mpr rfl
  rw [p] at h₁
  have q: (1 : R) - 0 = 1 := by norm_num
  rw [q] at h₁ 
  exact h₁
--Similarly $1=1 - (-a)^{n}=(1+a)(1+(-a)+(-a)^{2}+\cdots+(-a)^{n-1})$ 
--Thus $1+a$ is invertible  
  rcases h with ⟨n,hn⟩ 
  have h: (1 - a) * (∑ i ∈ Finset.range n, a ^ i) = 1 - a ^ n := by exact mul_neg_geom_sum a n
  use (∑ i ∈ Finset.range n, a ^ i)
  have q: (1 : R) - 0 = 1 := by norm_num
  rw [hn, q] at h
  exact h
691.informalProof:
1. In a ring with unity, prove that if $a$ is nilpotent, then $a+1$ and $a-1$ are both invertible. [HinT: Use the factorization $1-a^{n}=(1-a)\left(1+a+a^{2}+\cdots+a^{n-1}\right)$

for $1-a$, and a similar formula for $1+a$.]

2. In a commutative ring, prove that any product $x a$ of a nilpotent element $a$ by any element $x$ is nilpotent.

3.
In a commutative ring, prove that the sum of two nilpotent elements is nilpotent. (HinT: You must use the binomial formula; see Exercise L.)

An element $a$ of a ring is **unipotent** iff $1-a$ is nilpotent.

4. In a commutative ring, prove that the product of two unipotent elements $a$ and $b$ is unipotent. [HinT: Use the binomial formula to expand $1-a b=(1-a)+a(1-b)$ to power $n+m$.]

5. In a ring with unity, prove that every unipotent element is invertible. (Hint: Use Part 1.)

Proof.  
    1. $\because a$ is nilpotent $\therefore \exist n\in\mathbb N,s.t. a^{n}=0$.   
Thus $1=1 - a^{n}=(1-a)(1+a+a^{2}+\cdots+a^{n-1})$.  
 Thus $1-a$ is invertible.  
    Similarly $1=1 - (-a)^{n}=(1+a)(1+(-a)+(-a)^{2}+\cdots+(-a)^{n-1})$.  
 Thus $1+a$ is invertible.  
    2. $\because a$ is nilpotent $\therefore \exist n\in\mathbb N,s.t. a^{n}=0$.  
    By $R$ is a commutative ring $(xa)^{n}=x^{n}*a^{n}=0$.  
    3. $\because a$ is nilpotent $\therefore \exist n\in\mathbb N,s.t. a^{n}=0$.  
    $\because b$ is nilpotent $\therefore \exist m\in\mathbb N,s.t. b^{m}=0$.  
    By $R$ is a commutative ring $(a + b)^{n+m}=\sum_{r=0}^{r=n+m}C_{n+m}^{r}a^{r}*b^{n+m-r}$.  
    $\forall t\ge n,a^{t}=0$.  
    $\forall s\ge m,b^{s}=0$.  
    By $r+(n+m-r)=n+m$.  
 we have $r\ge n$ or $n+m-r\ge m$ If $r\ge n$ then $a^{r}=0$.  
 otherwise $n+m-r\ge m$ then $b^{n+m-r}=0$.  
 and both cases imply that $a^{r}*b^{n+m-r}=0$.  
    Thus $(a+b)^{n+m}=0,i.e.(a+b)$ is nilpotent.  
    4. It suffices to show that $1-ab$ is nilpotent.   
    By $1-ab=(1-a)+a(1-b)$, $1-a$ is nilpotent,  
    $1-b$ is nilpotent, $R$ is a commutative ring and the conclusions above,   
we have $a(1-b)$ is nilpotent and $(1-a)+a(1-b)$ is nilpotnet $i.e. (1-ab)$ is nilpotnet.  
    5.$\because (1-a)$ is nilpotent.  
 By the conclusions above we have $1-(1-a)$ is invertible $i.e. a$ is invertible

713.title: Exercise_1785
713.md: Let $A$ be an integral domain. Let $a \in A$. If $A$ has characteristic $\mathrm{p}$, and $\mathrm{n} \cdot a=0$ where $\mathrm{n}$ is not a multiple of $\mathrm{p}$, then $a=0$.
713.comment: 对于第四小问，我默认p是素数，因而p=0时0 ^ p 缺失良定义。
713.formalProof:
section Exercise_1785
namespace Exercise_1785

variable {A : Type*} [CommRing A] [IsDomain A] {p : ℕ} {a : A}

theorem Exercise_1785_part1 [CharP A p] (hn : n • a = 0) (hnp : ¬ p ∣ n) : a = 0 := by
  -- 由于 $A$ 的特征为 $p$，而条件给出 $p$ 不能整除 $n$，因此 $n * (1 : A) ≠ 0$。
  have h_n_ne_zero : ¬ (n : A) = 0  := by
    contrapose! hnp
    exact (CharP.cast_eq_zero_iff A p n).mp hnp
  -- 于是从 $n * a = 0$ 推出 $a = 0$。
  simp only [nsmul_eq_mul, mul_eq_zero, h_n_ne_zero, false_or] at hn
  exact hn

theorem Exercise_1785_part2 [h_p_Prime: Fact p.Prime] (ha : a ≠ 0) (hp : p • a = 0) : CharP A p := by
  -- 由 $a ≠ 0$ 推有 $p * (1 : A) = 0$，按定义，$A$ 的特征为 $p$。
  simp only [nsmul_eq_mul, mul_eq_zero, ha, or_false] at hp
  exact (CharP.charP_iff_prime_eq_zero h_p_Prime.out).mpr hp

theorem Exercise_1785_part3 [h_p_Prime: Fact p.Prime] (ha : a ≠ 0) {m : ℕ} (hpm : p ^ m • a = 0) : CharP A p := by
  -- 由 $a ≠ 0$ 推有 $m ≠ 0$。
  have : ¬ m = 0 := by
    contrapose! ha
    simp only [ha, pow_zero, one_smul] at hpm
    exact hpm
  -- 进而由 $m ≠ 0, a ≠ 0, p ^ m * (1 : A) = 0$ 联合推出 $p * (1 : A) = 0$。
  simp only [nsmul_eq_mul, Nat.cast_pow p m, mul_eq_zero, ne_eq, this, not_false_eq_true, pow_eq_zero_iff, ha, or_false] at hpm
  -- 按定义，$A$ 的特征为 $p$。
  exact ((CharP.charP_iff_prime_eq_zero (R := A) (p := p) h_p_Prime.out).mpr hpm)

def Exercise_1785_part4 (p : ℕ) [CharP A p] [h_p_Prime: Fact p.Prime] : RingHom A A := {
  toFun := fun x => x ^ p
  -- 保持幺元和乘法由环性质决定。
  map_one' := by
    simp only [one_pow]
  map_mul' := by
    intro x y
    simp only
    ring
  -- 由于 $p ≠ 0$，因而由环性质可以验证零元同样被保持。
  map_zero' := by
    simp only [ne_eq, NeZero.ne p, not_false_eq_true, zero_pow]
  -- 考虑交换环特征非 $0$ 时，有恒等式 $(x + y)^p = x^p + y^p$，因而加法同样被保持。
  map_add' := by
    intro x y
    simp only
    exact add_pow_char A x y
  -- 证明完成。
}

end Exercise_1785
end Exercise_1785
713.informalProof:
问题：
设 $A$ 是一个整环。证明以下 $1-4$ 部分：

1. 设 $a \in A$。如果 $A$ 的特征为 $p$，且 $n \cdot a=0$，其中 $n$ 不是 $p$ 的倍数，则 $a=0$。

2. 如果 $p$ 是素数，且存在非零元素 $a \in A$ 使得 $p \cdot a=0$，则 $A$ 的特征为 $p$。

3. 如果 $p$ 是素数，且存在非零元素 $a \in A$ 使得对某个整数 $m$，有 $p^m \cdot a=0$，则 $A$ 的特征为 $p$。

4. 如果 $A$ 的特征为 素数 $p$，则函数 $f(a)=a^p$ 是从 $A$ 到 $A$ 的同态映射。

证明：
- 1. 由于 $A$ 的特征为 $p$，而条件给出 $p$ 不能整除 $n$，因此 $n * (1 : A) ≠ 0$。于是从 $n * a = 0$ 推出 $a = 0$。
- 2. 由 $a ≠ 0$ 推有 $p * (1 : A) = 0$，按定义，$A$ 的特征为 $p$。
- 3. 由 $a ≠ 0$ 推有 $m ≠ 0$。进而由 $m ≠ 0, a ≠ 0, p ^ m * (1 : A) = 0$ 联合推出 $p * (1 : A) = 0$。按定义，$A$ 的特征为 $p$。
- 4. 保持幺元和乘法由环性质决定。
  5. 由于 $p ≠ 0$，因而由环性质可以验证零元同样被保持。
  6. 考虑交换环特征非 $0$ 时，有恒等式 $(x + y)^p = x^p + y^p$，因而加法同样被保持。

714.title: Exercise_1786
714.md: Let $A \subseteq B$ where $A$ and $B$ are integral domains. Prove: $A$ has characteristic $\mathrm{p}$ iff $B$ has characteristic $\mathrm{p}$.
714.formalProof:
import Mathlib
import Mathlib.Algebra.Group.Submonoid.Basic


example [CommRing B] [IsDomain B] (A : Subring B) : (ringChar B = p) ↔ (ringChar A = p) := by
  --We prove the equivalent proposition in two parts.
  constructor
  --From left to right, we simply know that for all x ∈ A, x ∈ B,too.
  · intro h
    apply ringChar.eq_iff.mpr
    apply ringChar.eq_iff.mp at h
    --So A has characteristic p.
    exact CharP.subsemiring B p A.toSubsemiring
  -- From right to left, we need to show that ∀ (x : ℕ), x * (1 : A) = 0 ↔ p ∣ x.
  · intro h
    apply ringChar.eq_iff.mpr
    apply ringChar.eq_iff.mp at h
    refine (charP_iff B p).mpr ?mpr.a
    rw [charP_iff] at h
    intro x
    specialize h x
    rcases h with ⟨h1, h2⟩
    --Notice that 1 ∈ B and 1 ∈ A at the same time. p * 1 = 0, and for all x ∈ A, p * x = p * 1 * x = 0.
    constructor
    · intro h'
      have zero_A : (x : A) = 0 := by
        exact ZeroMemClass.coe_eq_zero.mp h'
      exact h1 (h2 (h1 zero_A))
    · intro h'
      obtain hp := h2 (h')
      exact ZeroMemClass.coe_eq_zero.mpr hp
714.informalProof:
Proof  
1. We prove the equivalent proposition in two parts.
2. From left to right, we simply know that for all x ∈ A, x ∈ B,too.
3. So A has characteristic p.
4. From right to left, we need to show that ∀ (x : ℕ), x * (1 : A) = 0 ↔ p ∣ x.
5. Notice that 1 ∈ B and 1 ∈ A at the same time. p * 1 = 0, and for all x ∈ A, p * x = p * 1 * x = 0.

732.title: Exercise_1853
732.md: 6 Suppose $a(x)$ and $b(x)$ have degree $<n$. If $a(c)=b(c)$ for $n$ values of $c$, prove that $a(x)=b(x)$.
732.formalProof:
import mathlib
import Mathlib.Tactic.ComputeDegree

open Finset
open Polynomial

example {n : ℕ} (a b : ℝ[X]) (ha : degree a < n) (hb : degree b < n)(hc :Multiset.card (roots (a - b))= n) : a = b := by
  by_contra t
  --We prove this problem by using the reductio ad absurdum.
  have h : a - b ≠ 0 := by exact sub_ne_zero_of_ne t
  --First of all,   if $a \neq b$, then  $a-b \neq 0$.
  have h1 : Multiset.card (roots (a - b)) ≤ (a - b).degree := by exact card_roots h
  --By using a corollary of the fundamental theorem of algebra, we immediately know that the number of the roots of $a-b$ less than or equal to the degree of it.
  have h2 : (a + (-b)).degree ≤  max a.degree (-b).degree := by
    exact Polynomial.degree_add_le a (-b)
  have h3 : max a.degree (-b).degree < n := by
    have f : (-b).degree = b.degree := by exact degree_neg b
    rw[← f] at hb
    exact max_lt ha hb
  have h4 : (a + (-b)).degree < n := by exact lt_of_le_of_lt h2 h3
  have h5 : (a + (-b)).degree = (a - b).degree := by exact rfl
  rw[h5] at h4
  --Consider that degree of $a$ , $b$ less than $n$.So, the degree of $a - b$ less than $n$.
  have h6 : Multiset.card (roots (a - b)) < n := by
    exact_mod_cast lt_of_le_of_lt h1 h4
  -- Imediately, we get that the number of the roots of $a-b$ less than $n$.
  rw[hc] at h6
  exact (lt_self_iff_false n).mp h6
  --This contradicts condition the number of the roots of $a-b$ is $n$.

782.title: Exercise_1913
782.md: Let $U$ and $V$ have the same dimension $n$. Prove that $h$ is injective iff $h$ is surjective.
782.formalProof:
import Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.FiniteDimensional
import Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.LinearIndependent
import Mathlib
import Mathlib.Tactic
import MIL.Common

open FiniteDimensional
-- Define K as a field and U, V as finite-dimensional vector spaces over K
variable (K : Type) [Field K]
variable (U V : Type) [AddCommGroup U] [Module K U]
variable [AddCommGroup V] [Module K V]
variable [FiniteDimensional K U] [FiniteDimensional K V]

lemma injective_iff_surjective_of_finrank_eq_finrank [FiniteDimensional K U]
    [FiniteDimensional K V] (H : FiniteDimensional.finrank K U = FiniteDimensional.finrank K V) {f : U →ₗ[K] V} :
    Function.Injective f ↔ Function.Surjective f := by
  have := LinearMap.finrank_range_add_finrank_ker f
  rw [← LinearMap.ker_eq_bot, ← LinearMap.range_eq_top]; refine' ⟨fun h => _, fun h => _⟩
  · rw [h, finrank_bot, add_zero, H] at this
    exact Submodule.eq_top_of_finrank_eq this
  · rw [h, finrank_top, H] at this
    exact Submodule.finrank_eq_zero.1 (add_right_injective _ this)

817.title: Exercise_2042
817.md: 29. Show that if $G$ is a finite group with identity $e$ and with an even number of elements, then there is $a \neq e$ in $G$ such that $a * a=e$.
817.formalProof:
/-
Show that if $G$ is a finite group with identity $e$ and with an even number of elements, then there is $a \neq e$ in $G$ such that $a * a = e$.
First by Sylow's first theorem any group whose order is divided by 2 has a 2-group as its subgroup, where 2-group denotes the group whose order is exactly the power of 2.
So it suffices to prove that any 2-group contains an element of order 2. Then we can obtain the result we desire.
Let $K$ be the 2-subgroup of $G$m and $C$ be the center of $K$. we know that the center of a p-group is always nontrivial, thus we can always select an element $x \in C$ that is not equal to $e$.
Since the order of $x$ has to divide the order of $K$, thus it must be a power of 2 which is not $1$.
Then $u = x^{\text{orderof} x / 2}$ is just an element of order 2, because
1. $u$ is not equal to $e$ since $\text{orderof} x / 2$ is less the order of $x$.
2. $u * u = e$ by some simple simplification and the definition of order.
Finally combining the observations above we have proven that any group of even order contain an element of order 2.
-/
example {G : Type*} [Group G] [Fintype G] (h : 2 ∣ Fintype.card G) : ∃ (a : G), a ≠ 1 ∧ a * a = 1 := by
  -- First by Sylow's first theorem any group whose order is divided by 2 has a 2-group as its subgroup, where 2-group denotes the group whose order is exactly the power of 2.
  haveI : ∀ H : Subgroup G, Fintype H := fun H => Fintype.ofFinite H
  have pow_dvd_card : 2^1 ∣ Fintype.card G := h
  obtain ⟨K, hK⟩ := Sylow.exists_subgroup_card_pow_prime 2 pow_dvd_card
  have card_k_gt_1 : 1 < Fintype.card K := by
    simp only [pow_one] at hK
    have p : 1 < 2 := by norm_num
    suffices hcard : @Fintype.card (↥K) (this K)= 2 from Nat.lt_of_lt_of_eq p (id (Eq.symm hcard))
    rw [← hK]
    convert rfl
  have nontrivial_K : Nontrivial K := by
    rw [← Finite.one_lt_card_iff_nontrivial]; simp; exact card_k_gt_1
  have K_is_p_group : IsPGroup 2 K := by
    apply IsPGroup.of_card
    rw [← hK]
    convert rfl
  -- So it suffices to prove that any 2-group contains an element of order 2. Then we can obtain the result we desire.
  have exists_for_2p_group : (K : Subgroup G) → (Nontrivial K) → (IsPGroup 2 K) → ∃ (a : K), a ≠ 1 ∧ a * a = 1 := by
    -- Let $K$ be the 2-subgroup of $G$m and $C$ be the center of $K$. we know that the center of a p-group is always nontrivial, thus we can always select an element $x \in C$ that is not equal to $e$.
    intro K ntk pgk
    let C : Subgroup K := Subgroup.center K
    have nontrivial_center : Nontrivial C := by apply IsPGroup.center_nontrivial pgk
    rw [Subgroup.nontrivial_iff_exists_ne_one] at nontrivial_center
    let ⟨x, ⟨_, hneq1⟩⟩ := nontrivial_center
    -- Since the order of $x$ has to divide the order of $K$, thus it must be a power of 2 which is not $1$.
    have xorder_is_pow_of_2 : ∃ r : Nat, orderOf x = 2^r := IsPGroup.iff_orderOf.mp pgk x
    let ⟨r, hxr⟩ := xorder_is_pow_of_2
    have rgt0 : r ≠ 0 := by
      by_contra hr0
      have : x = 1 := by rw [← orderOf_eq_one_iff, hxr, hr0]; norm_num
      contradiction
    -- Then $u = x^{\text{orderof} x / 2}$ is just an element of order 2, because
    use x^(2^(r-1))
    constructor
    -- 1. $u$ is not equal to $e$ since $\text{orderof} x / 2$ is less the order of $x$.
    · apply pow_ne_one_of_lt_orderOf'
      simp only [ne_eq, pow_eq_zero_iff', OfNat.ofNat_ne_zero, false_and, not_false_eq_true]
      rw [hxr, Nat.pow_lt_pow_iff_right];
      simp only [tsub_lt_self_iff, zero_lt_one, and_true]
      exact Nat.zero_lt_of_ne_zero rgt0; norm_num
    -- 2. $u * u = e$ by some simple simplification and the definition of order.
    · rw [← npow_add, ← Nat.two_pow_succ];
      calc
        x^(2^(r - 1 + 1)) = x^(2^r) := by rw [Nat.sub_add_cancel]; exact Nat.zero_lt_of_ne_zero rgt0
        _ = 1 := by rw [← pow_orderOf_eq_one x, hxr]
  -- Finally combining the observations above we have proven that any group of even order contain an element of order 2.
  obtain ⟨a, ⟨han1, hao2⟩⟩ := exists_for_2p_group K nontrivial_K K_is_p_group
  use a
  constructor
  · by_contra ha1
    rw [OneMemClass.coe_eq_one] at ha1; contradiction
  · rw [Subtype.ext_iff] at hao2; exact hao2
817.informalProof:
/-
Show that if $G$ is a finite group with identity $e$ and with an even number of elements, then there is $a \neq e$ in $G$ such that $a * a = e$.
First by Sylow's first theorem any group whose order is divided by 2 has a 2-group as its subgroup, where 2-group denotes the group whose order is exactly the power of 2.
So it suffices to prove that any 2-group contains an element of order 2. Then we can obtain the result we desire.
Let $K$ be the 2-subgroup of $G$m and $C$ be the center of $K$. we know that the center of a p-group is always nontrivial, thus we can always select an element $x \in C$ that is not equal to $e$.
Since the order of $x$ has to divide the order of $K$, thus it must be a power of 2 which is not $1$.
Then $u = x^{\text{orderof} x / 2}$ is just an element of order 2, because
1. $u$ is not equal to $e$ since $\text{orderof} x / 2$ is less the order of $x$.
2. $u * u = e$ by some simple simplification and the definition of order.
Finally combining the observations above we have proven that any group of even order contain an element of order 2.
-/

818.title: Exercise_2044
818.md: 31. If $*$ is a binary operation on a set $S$, an element $x$ of $S$ is an idempotent for $*$ if $x * x=x$. Prove that a group has exactly one idempotent element. (You may use any theorems proved so far in the text.)
818.formalProof:
import Mathlib

--Let $G$ be a group.
variable {G : Type*} [Group G]

--Let $ide= \{ x$ $|$ $x*x=x \}$ be a subset of $G$.
def ide : Set G := {x | x * x = x}

--Show that $ide=\{1\}$.
example : ide = ({1} : Set G) := by
  --Let $x$ be a element of $G$.
  ext x
  constructor
  --Show that for any element $x$ in the group $G$, if $x \in ide$, then $x=1$.
  · intro hx
    --Because if $x \in ide$, we have $x=x^{-1}*(x*x)=x^{-1}*x=1$.
    calc
      x = x⁻¹ * (x * x) := by group
      _= x⁻¹ * x := by rw [hx]
      _= 1 := by group
  · --On the other hand, 1 is obviously in $ide$.
    intro hx
    rw [hx]
    show 1 * 1 = 1
    group

import Mathlib

example {G : Type*} [Group G] (a b : G) (h : a * b = b * a⁻¹) : b * a = a⁻¹ * b := by
